M.P.A. HANKEY,Secretary, Cabinet.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.128th January, 1930. I E C R E T.Copy No.C A B I N E T.ADDENDUM TO THE AGENDAforMeeting to "be Held at 10, Downing Street, S.W.1.on Wednesday, January 29th, 1930, at 11 a.m.CO AH.(Statement to be made by the President ofthe Board of Trade.)(Sgd.) M.P.A. HANKEY,Secretary, Cabinet.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1.January 28th, 1930. A G E N D A.1. HOURS OF INDUSTRIAL EMPLOYMENT BILL.'Memorandum by the Minister of Labour.(CP. 26 (30) - already circulated)3. AGRICULTURAL MARKETING BILL.(Reference Cabinet 2 (30) Conclusion 2 (d))Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture andFisheries.(CP. 25 (30) - already circulated)IMPERIAL CONFERENCE AND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE.(Reference Cabinet 2 (30) Conclusion 4 )Memorandum by the Secretary of State for DominionAffairs..(CP. 28 (30) - circulated herewith).(THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)SECRET. Copy No.cabinet 5 (30).Meeting of the Cabinet to be held at 10, downing street, S.W.I., on Wednesday, January 29th, 1930,at 11 a. m. (Sgd.) M.P.A. HANKEY.Secretary, Cabinet.whitehall Gardens, S.W.1.27th January, 1930.6. UNEMPLOYMENT POLICY.(Reference Cabinet 4 (30) Conclusion 4)Memorandum by the Lord Privy Seal.(CP. 21 (30) - already circulated)TO TAKE NOTE OF:7. PRIVATE MEMBERS1 BILLS.(I) Canal Boats Bill: Second Reading.(Mr. Gosling (LA))(ii) Omnibuses Bill: Second Reading.(Commander Kenworthy (LA))(iii) Slaughter of Animals Bill: Second Reading.(Colonel Moore (C))(iv) Coal Mines (Protection of Animals) Bill:Second Reading.(Sir Robert Gower (C)). - 62A(THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY-OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT).S E C R E T.Copy NoCABINET 5 (30).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet held at10, Downing Street, S.W.I., on Wednesday,January 29th, 1930, at 11.0 a.m.PRESENT:The Right Hon. J.Prime Minister,The Right Hon.Philip Snowden, M.P.,Chancellor of theExchequer.say MacDonald, M.P.,(In the Chair).The Right Hon.Arthur Henderson, M.P.,Secretary of State forForeign Affairs.The Right Hon.3.H. Thomas, M.P.,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon.-Lord Passfield, Secretaryof State for Dominion affairs and Secretary of Statefor the Colonies.The Right Hon.Lord Parmoor of Frieth,K.C.V.O., K.C., lord president of the Council,The Right Hon.Lord Sankey, G.B.E.,Lord Chancellor.The Right Hon.J.R. Clynes, M.P.,Secretary of State for home Affairs.The Right Hon.Tom Shaw, C.B.E., M.P.,Secretary of State forWar. :The Right Hon.Arthur Greenwood, M.P.,Minister of Health.The Right Hon.Noel Buxton, M.P.,Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries.The Right Hon,.William Graham, M.P.,President of the Boardof Trade.The Right Hon.William Adamson, M.P.,Secretary of State forScotland.The Ripcht Hon.W. Wedgwood Benn, D.S.O.,D.F.C., M.P., Secretary ofState for India.Brig.-Gen. The Right Hon.Lord Thomson, C.B.E., D.S.O.,Secretary of State forAir.The Right Hon.Margaret Bondfield, M.P.,Minister of Labour.The Right Hon.Sir Charles Trevelyan, Bt.,M.P., President of theBoard of Education.The Right Hon.A.V. Alexander, M.P.,First Lord of theAdmiralty.The Right Hon.George Lansbury, M.P.,First Commissioner ofWorks.Mr. Thomas Jones, C.H.Deputy Secretary. RUSSIA..(Previous Ref-erence:Cabinet 36(29)Conclusion 1).1. THE SECRETARY Gi' STATE FOR FOREIGN affairs informed the Cabinet that on January 25th theHjgyiet Government had replied to the Britishmemorandum a January 6th which indicated the preLijaiaa&ry proposals of Hie Majesty'aGovernment fax a settlement of outstanding questions. It would appear from their reply-that the Soviet Government were ready again to sign the 1924 Treaties, though they think thatcertain alterations would be desirable. .The Soviet reply about the question of claims anddebts is indefinite, but it appears to indicatethat they regard the whole of the chapter aboutclaims and debts and Chapter 1 of the 1924 treaty as inseparable, i.e, they will probably take theline that a debts and claim settlement isimpossible without a loan.The Secretary of State added that the Sovietroply was being examined by an interdepartmental committee and that he proposed to adhere generally to the Memorandum of January 6th. egypt.ANGLO-egyptian treaty.(Previous Ref-erence:Cabinet 39(29)Conclusion 4(a))2, The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs(Paper CP.23(30)) covering a telegram fromHi& Majesty1 s High Commissioxier in Egypt and adraft reply regarding negotiations for theconclusion of a Treaty with Egypt.The Cabinet agreed To authorise the Secretary of Statefor Foreign affairs to proceed withthe negotiations on the lines indicated in his memorandum and inhis draft reply to Sir percy loraine. SEPAL AND TIBET. 3. THE SECRETARY OP STATE FOR INDIA called attention to a threatened outbreak of hostilities between Nepal and Tibet arising out of the murder of a subject of the former State. The cabinet were informed that British relations with Nepalwere governed by a Treaty of 1923 by which wewere under obligation to supply arms to Nepal.Our representative had been asked to press uponthe Nepal Government the advisability ofrefraining from action pending the results ofefforts at mediation now sbeing made by a specialemissary at Lhasa.The Cabinet agreed That the position should be examined by the Secretary of State for Indiaand the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs who should reportto the Prime Minister as soon aspossible. HOURS OF IHDUSTRT1L 4. The cabinet had before them a MemorandumavlPIOYMSNT BILL.(Paper c.P, 26(30) ) by the Minister of Labourkprevious Ref- covering a Memorandum by the Attorney-General '"erence;Cabinet 3(30) setting out certain points relating particularlyConclusion 4).to overtime and"the position of the Railways.The Memorandum "and:its proposals had been agreed with the Secretary of State for Dominion affairs and the President of the Board of Trade.In the course of the discussion the cabinet were informed that it was hoped to introduce theBill in the first week in ^arch and that theproposals of the Memorandum had the concurrence ofthe officials of the International Labour Office.The Cabinet agreed To approve the proposals as set forth in the Minister of Labour's memorandum and to authorise the Minister to consult the appropriate Unions in regard to themwith the assistance of the General Councilof the Trades Union Congress. UNSMPL0M3STINSURANCE BILL.I (Previous Kef-' erence:Cabinet 2(30)Conclusion 2(b))5. The Cabinet had before them a Statement bythe Lord President of the Council (Paper CP.29(30))dealing with two important amendments to theUnemployment Insurance Bill made jJa the House ofLords. The first is a new Clause 4; and thesecond limits the operation of the Bill to oneyear from the 1st April next.THE LORD PRESIDENT OF THE COUNCIL said that since he had circulated his Memorandum he had learned that if the Bill were returned to the lords from the Commons in ifcs original form the lords/-**edi^rpxodJSKEy "disagree' and the Bill wouldthen drou/ To prevent this it was desirableto attempt to reach some accommodation on thedate limiting the operation of the Bill. This,Lord Parmoor thought, would be possible and in hisopinion the Lords w^ould not^/insist on the new clause 4.The Cabinet agreed:-(a) That the Lords' Amendment limiting the operation of the UnemploymentInsurance Bill to a period ending march 31, 1931, should be amended by the substitution of June 30, 1933^as the limit.(b) That in connection with Clause 4the Minister of Labour should move to disagree with the Lords' Amendment. GOAL. 6. THE PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD OF TRADE gave the Cabinet an account of the negotiations in(Previous Ref-erences: regard to the Coal Bill now before Parliament.Cabinet 50(29)Conclusion 5 Mr. Graham stated that general agreement had beenandCabinet 2(30) ^ reached in regard to Hours, the National IndustrialConclusion 2(c))Board, and Amalgamation Schemes, but substantialdifficulty remained in regard to Part I of the Bill,which dealt with Marketing Schemes. The Governmentwere being urged to postpone Part I until after the amalgamation proposals had been dealt with. further conversations were to take place to-day.In the course of the discussion it was suggestedthat the Governments policy in regard to Part i could be announced in advance by means of question and Answer in Parliament, and this proceduremet with general approval.The Cabinet agreed That the President of the Board of trade should continue the negotiations inthe light of the Cabinet discussion and should report to the Coal Committee. NAVAL CONSTRUCTIONFROGRAMME ANDREPORT OF FIGHTINGSERVICES COMMIT TEE".(Previous Ref-erence:Cabinet 4(30)Conclusion 2.and Appendix).7. The Cabinet bad before them a Report Of theFighting Services Committee (Paper CP. 2(30)).The Cabinet agreed (a) To adopt the Report of theFighting Services Committee;(b) To authorise the First lord to give the information on theNaval Programme asked for in a house of Commons Question bythe Member for Devonport that afternoon. G-RI CULTURALiKLTIUG BILL.reyious Ref-abxnet 2(30)conclusion 2(d))8. The Cabinet had under consideration aMemorandum by the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries (Paper CP. 25(30)) giving particulars of proposals for an agricultural marketing Bill, the object of which would beto facilitate the organisation of producersinto Associations or Corporations under their own control and, subject to appropriatesafeguards, for greater unity of effort in marketing.In the course of the discussion stress was laid on the importance of not overlookingthe interests of consumers in the legislationproposed, and on the desirability of havingthe proposals of the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries in the form of a draft Bill.The Cabinet agreed (a) To approve generally the principlesunderlying the proposals of theMinister of Agriculture andFisheries in regard to the marketing of commodities;(b) To refer the Memorandum of theMinister of Agriculture and fisheries to a Committee consisting of:The Minister of Agriculture and fisheries the President of the Board of Trade,The Secretary of State for Scotland,The First Lord of the Admiralty;for examination and for the preparationof a Draft Bill to be submitted in thefirst instance to the Cabinet;(c) To draw the special attention of theCommittee to the need of safeguarding the interests of consumers and of considering the legislation for aConsumers' Council in preparation atthe Board of Trade. IMPERIAL CONFERENCE 94 The Cabinet had before them aAND SCONOAIICCONFERENCE. Memorandum by the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs (Paper CP. 28(30)) regarding(Previous Ref- arrangements for Meetings of an Imperialerence:Cabinet 2(30) Economic Committee.Conclusion 4).The Cabinet agreed To accept the suggestion of theSecretary of State for DominionAffairs that the ImperialConference and the EconomicConference should runconcurrently. AGRICULTURE. 10. THE MIEISTa&I OF LABOUR called attentionUNEMr'employment to a motion about tc be taken in the House of insurance BILL.Commons on the question of the insurance of(Previous Ref- agricultural workers against unemploymenterenee:Cabinet 42(29) and asked for the direction of the cabinet conclusion 4).as to the reply to be givexi on behalf ofthe Government.The Cabinet agreed That the Minister of Labour should state that the matter was receiving-consideration and especially itsdifficult financial aspects; that ithad always been recognised that theeconomic position of agricultural workers differed from other industrial workers, and that it had often been urged that any insurance scheme suited to their circumstances would haveto be separated from other insurance schemes; the solution of these difficulties must take time and it wouldnot be possible to introduce legislation during this session to give effectto the Government1s policy. LFiATCAGiO OF 11. TEH! I'Aim MINISTER' called attention-to111 FORMAT I OH;a number of serious leakages of secretofficial information dealing with Retirement(Previous Ref-erence: Pensions, Admiralty Estimates, etc., which cabinet 1(30)Conclusion 4). had taken place within the last few days,and impressed upon his colleagues the needfor the utmost caution in dealing withrepresentatives of the Press. SF'EMPL0YM3NT 12. The Cabinet had before them thePOLICY.Memorandum by the Lord Privy Seal(Paper CP.21 (SO/.) on the subject of a(previous Ref-erence : speech he recently made in Manchester regardingCabinet ,4(30)Conclusion 4). the general unemployment policy of theGovernment.The Cabinet agreed To hold a special meeting ofthe Cabinet cn Monday next,February 3rd, 1930, at 11.0 a*m.to discuss Unemployment,2 Whitehall Gardens, 3 .w,1,29th January 1930,-lei-
